Comments_List: I developed an understanding of the deeply rooted infrastructure of slavery that manifests itself in different ways in modern society.

This eye-opening course taught me about how the past influences the present in the context of the founding of the United States. I learned a lot about how terms like "race" and "ethnicity" came to be, especially in the context of historical moments.
Analysis primary sources and critically relating historical texts throughout different periods of time.

Strengths: This course was absolutely amazing and mind-blowing. I think this course should be a requirement for every student. I loved our discussions and Professor Camacho's lectures, where we connected historical moments to certain topics related to race. I liked our discussions looking at the present day, especially those incorporating current news items. This class does have its fair share of reading, but the reading is always very interesting and informative. We dispel a lot of the myths associated with the United States that are still taught in classes today, and I really appreciated this. This is honestly one of the most informative and realistic history courses you'll ever take.

Weaknesses: Sometimes the class was a little disorganized, and I wish we had been able to cover more topics in depth, but I understand that this was an intro course so we couldn't cover everything. Also, I feel like we could have covered more topics outside of the United States, but I understand that that would have been very difficult because of the time constraint.
The duration was too short, leading the material to be extremely condense. Designating more time.

Absolutely! This class should be a requirement for every student. You will learn more in this course in two weeks than you've ever probably learned in any history course. American history is inseparable from issues related to ethnicity, race, and migration, and it really should not be taught separately. I liked that we looked at American history through the lens of marginalized people, those voices usually relegated to the sidelines. I think it was important in relating past issues to the present day.
